properties.media:imagetext:
DELTA'S
PASSENGERS
ARE SPECIAL
PEOPLE
And children are some
of our very best travelers
We're often asked, "Can my child travel alone?",
"What arrangements do I need to make?",
, and
"How will Delta take care of my child?". It is our
pleasure to offer this pamphlet as an answer to those
questions. We've designed it with you in mind—a
guide for parents or guardians of children traveling
unaccompanied on Delta Air Lines. To make it easy
to read, we've highlighted your responsibilities in blue.
So if you're unable to travel with your child, relax-
let Delta's Professionals assist you.
Conditions of
acceptance
Your child may travel alone on Delta if he is at least
5 years of age. Children under 5 are considered
too young to travel alone and must be accompanied
by a responsible person at least 12 years of age.
Unaccompanied children pay the full applicable
adult fare.
There are two general provisions that apply to
children traveling alone. Delta will accept
unaccompanied minors for domestic transportation
provided that:
1) The child is brought to the airport of origina-
tion by a parent or responsible adult who will
remain with the child until the aircraft is
boarded, and furnishes satisfactory evidence
that the child will be met by another parent
or responsible adult at the destination airport.
2) There are no pre-existing weather conditions
or other known operating irregularities that
might prevent the flight from landing at the
destination airport.
In addition, children 5, 6, and 7 years of age must
use Delta for the entire trip—one-plane through
service with no change of aircraft from origin to
destination. Those children who are at least 8 years
of age are accepted for all flights, including Delta-to-
Delta connections and connections to and from
other airlines. However, reservations must be
confirmed to the destination. Please keep in mind,
too, that some airlines have acceptance practices
which differ from Delta's, including restrictions
on the hours during which unaccompanied children
may travel. Also, if there is any question as to
the child's age, a birth certificate may be
requested.
Delta will accept unaccompanied children for
international travel subject to the same conditions
as domestic travel shown above. In addition and with
reference only to those 5, 6, and 7 years old,
the flight cannot be scheduled to stop in a country
other than the country of origin or destination.
And, of course, all children must possess the
necessary travel documents (passport, visas, etc.)
Delta will be happy to provide full details in this
regard as well as international fare information
when you call for reservations.
Making Reservations
Part of the fun of traveling alone is in the anticipation
of it. Let your child share in that by including him
in the travel plans and decisions whenever possible.
He's more likely to accept the responsibility of
traveling alone knowing that you trust him. At the
time reservations are made, our agent will need
to know:
1) The name and age of your child;
2) The name, address, and telephone
number of the adult who will be respon-
sible for bringing the child to the airport;
3) The name, address, and telephone
number of the adult who will be respon-
sible for meeting the child at the
destination airport.
Your child should know, or have, all of this
information with him as he travels too.
At the Airport
When checking in for the flight, please advise
our ticket agent that your child is traveling
alone. He will complete a special "On-Board
Message" with all pertinent information concerning
the unaccompanied status of your child. If your
reservation requires a change of plane to
another airline, it will also be necessary to
complete and sign an Unaccompanied Minor
Information Form. Both forms will accompany
your child's ticket. You should plan to remain
at the airport until the child has boarded and
the aircraft has departed.
We want to assure you that Delta will take good
care of your child from the time of acceptance
until he is met by the party specified at the desti-
nation. Our agent will affix a special button to
your child's outer garment for identification
purposes. Then he will be escorted onboard the
aircraft and introduced to the flight attendant.
If you so desire, Delta will make every effort to
allow you to accompany your child onboard to see
that he is settled. However this is not always
possible. We will attempt to seat your child where
our flight attendants can give him their best
attention (that is, in the front of the cabin, in a
non-smoking area and with other children who may
also be traveling alone).
Up, Up, and Away
Although our flight attendants try to give extra
attention to unaccompanied minors, their onboard
duties prevent them from entertaining the child
fulltime. We suggest that your child bring along
a favorite toy, game, or book. A familiar plaything
will often add to his sense of security and make the
time without you pass quickly. It is a good idea to
put your child's name on any item (including coats
and jackets) that he brings onboard with him.
Dress your child in casual play clothes-simple,
loose-fitting garments that he can nap and lounge
in comfortably and manage easily when he uses
millsfield:images_texts:
ADELTA AIR LINES
Guide for
Children
Traveling
Alone
That's the Delta
Spirit!*

attendants have received extensive first-aid
training. In the event of serious illness, on Delta's
domestic system our flights are seldom more than
20 minutes from an airport where emergency
services are available.
We hope we've answered most of your questions
about children traveling alone on Delta and removed
any possible sources of concern. We would be
happy to explain specific requirements regarding
your child or handle your special requests.
Just give Delta or your favorite Travel Agent a call.
Know, too, that you'll be giving your child more
than just a wonderful trip. You'll be giving him
memories that last a lifetime.
THAT'S THE
DELTA SPIRIT!™
© Delta Air Lines 9/84
Printed in U.S.A.
Form 0412-80738
Brochure 11-84
2003,105, 373
